BE11:17am

While the timing of the departure may come as a surprise to the market, internally the succession planning has been in process over the past three years. Julian has been working part time in the business for the past nine months and there is no change to James Holder's role from a design function perspective. The design team consists of c. 60 people and is tried and tested over several seasons (we evidenced the strength of the team at last year's capital markets day).

The company has not updated on current trade, but has re-iterated its previous guidance (confident of delivering FY18E PBT in line with range of £97.7m to £100.6m - CGe £98.1m).

In common with other retailers, we suspect that the snow across Europe will have hit short term trade, but we think that there are plenty of levers to pull in the business and short term volatility should not detract from the longer term growth potential.

Cal. 18E PE 15.4x. Maintain Buy.

wayneJ BE - u no longer giving us updates on frock shops? Are u going to upgrade to hoodie emporiums?
Soundbuy @Lemmy - dodgy translation of no tumble dry?
BE11:17am

And Liberum.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

The vision, focus and values behind a brand let alone the design ethos all combine to drive the commercial success. As Tom Joules has been crucial to the success of Joules, so has Ray Kelvin been for Ted Baker. While both Tom Joules and Ray Kelvin have gone to extra-ordinary lengths to build significant depth in all areas of their business, and demonstrated this, we are not overly convinced this happened at SuperDry. Joules and Ted Baker have massively invested in their infrastructure, IT and systems but alongside the early recognition of the structural changes taking place across the global retail environment, they have brought in highly talented people across all areas of their business. However the founders remain the strategic focus for the group and values behind the brand. At SuperDry we have not only seen senior executive roles change over the years, and more recently with the upcoming departure of the CFO. We think management should alleviate concerns that the exit of the founders will not in any way diminish the design process, and that the brand remains in a robust position expressing they have the necessary skills across all areas of the Group. In a market place that is clearly changing rapidly we see today’s announcement as an increase in SuperDry risk profile reflected in our TP decrease which suggests a fair value of 19.5x PE.

BE11:18am

And Investec.

BE11:18am

Julian has increasingly stepped back from the business in recent years, handing over the day-to-day running of the business
to Euan Sutherland in October 2014, to focus on Product and Brand. We see Julian’s departure as a natural evolution and
he leaves in place experienced, well-resourced and fully integrated Design/Category Management/Merchandising teams.
Both Siri MacDonald, Head of Womenswear Design and Helen Harding, Head of Womenswear Category Management, have
been at Superdry 4 years. Dan Hanvey, Head of Menswear Design, has been at Superdry nearly 14 years with Laura
Dugdale, Head of Menswear Category Management, 5 years. Management confirms it is looking to hire a Creative Director
as well.

Valuation (CY18e PE 15.6x) looks undemanding for a company capable of delivering mid/high teens earnings growth per
annum for the foreseeable future in our view. It is early days implementing the Superdry 5.0 strategy, which is about delivering a digitally-led, multi-channel global growth strategy and starting to leverage a well-invested infrastructure. Short/medium term growth drivers are European expansion & self-help opportunities. The USA & China are seen as long-term growth drivers.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

GSK and Novartis have announced that Novartis is putting its 36.5% stake in the Consumer Health joint venture back to GSK (as per agreement Novartis is able to do this from 2 March) for £9.2bn (expected close Q2). The valuation is broadly consistent with the contingent liability on GSK's balance sheet (£8.6bn as of end December) and at 18x LTM EBIT/3x LTM sales seems sensible to us.

BE11:37am

Assuming GSK will finance this mostly out of commercial paper initially and then refinance the amount in bonds, we estimate a net accretion potential to earnings after interest payments of c3% (the forgone minority pay-away amounts to 7% of EPS). Of note, GSK now talks about Consumer Health margin potential in the mid-20s by 2022 which is ahead of the current target of greater than 20% by 2020, suggesting the potential accretion could rise over time.

BE11:37am

After walking away from bidding for the Pfizer OTC business last Friday for returns and capital allocation priority reasons (as per company press release), we do not see GSK return to the bidding process. The Novartis put has always been the #2 capital allocation priority for GSK CEO (investment in pharma is priority #1) and we believe all of the above is hence consistent with GSK's prior statement on capital allocation.

red @VV75plus500 up 5% on day while others down. doesnt take a genius to work out who is affected most
11:37 am
BE11:37am

And Kepler.

BE11:38am

Consumer Health has become less appealing after a slowdown in market growth recorded by a number of key players, including GSK and Bayer – GSK now expects low-single-digit 2018 growth. However, this was a well-flagged capital allocation priority, and GSK said that the put option (in terms of size and timing) was creating inherent uncertainty for capital planning. Furthermore, GSK has done well in operating margin improvement of the JV, increasing it from 11.3% in 2015 to 17.7%.

BE11:38am

This deal looks more appealing than the Pfizer USD20bn Consumer Health business; GSK was in pole position for acquiring this, and the stock was up almost 4% last week after GSK reportedly pulled out of the deal. Given the deal raises GSK’s net debt/EBITDA from 1.7x to 2.7x, we think this stops GSK from doing meaningful M&A in the near- to mid-term.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

And Morgan Stanley.

Arash Massoudi, FT @BE: Have picked up lots of background on what happened inside GSK last Tuesday-Friday. Will make sure that ends up in our copy today and in DD, ML readers should keep an eye out for that if interested
BE11:39am

Timing is a bit more surprising given recent comments from Novartis CEO suggesting they were in no rush to sell. Completion of the deal is expected in summer 2018. The value is close to what was anticipated - GSK already had £8.8bn booked as short term liability on its balance sheet ($12.5bn at current rates). We calculate that this transaction should lead to a 2% EPS accretion and 2018 Net Debt/EBITDA ratio of ~2.0x for GSK, post asset sales. GSK expects the strategic review for its consumer assets to be completed around end 2018. We also note that the press release suggests a margin uplift - GSK now forecasts mid-20s margins by 2022 (we have 22% in 2022). We see this dealas a clear positive for both companies -clarification for both, more flexibility in cash allocation for Novartis, strategic move for GSK. We do not expect this move to put the dividend at risk as it decreases the risk of a large scale M&A.

red ig and cmc are positioning themselves towards more professional clients so the higher the legal bar the less of them they can get. and of course higher margin req means lower profits for them.

BE11:41am

Okay, so CFDs.

BE11:41am

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Peel Hunt can summarise.

Punter @BE, red, arash thanks for grey etc on GSK, very helpful.
BE11:42am

 Leverage limits on the opening of a position between 30:1 and 2:1, depending on the price volatility of the underlying asset (slightly more strenuous than the 30:1 and 5:1 in the initial proposal with the more strenuous limit applied to the cryptocurrency asset class).
 A 50% margin close out rule applied on a per account basis (better than on a trade basis that might have been the case).
 Negative balance protection, limiting retail clients’ liability to the funds in their CFD trading account (broadly consistent with the initial proposal).
 A prohibition on firms offering monetary and non-monetary benefits (excluding research and information tools) to retail investors (broadly consistent with the initial proposal).
 A standardised risk warning, including firm-specific figures on the percentage of client accounts that have lost money trading CFDs (broadly consistent with the initial proposal).
 A prohibition on the marketing, distribution or sale of binary options to retail investors (consistent with the initial proposal).

red thing about being a professional client is that you lose option to refer to FOS

There was talk of self certification in the last set of Plus500 numbers. Which might be another regulatory quagmire further down the road, or not, who knows? Back to Peel Hunt.

red but you do lose FOS which i think is imp here
BE11:45am

These new proposals, whilst not without their challenges, should end the regulatory uncertainty that has depressed this sector. There is still the question as to the impact of leverage limits on client behaviour, and it will take some time to see the impact on revenues. The positives remain that the industry will now have a level playing field, improved standards, and that there is the prospect of increased market shares and possibly higher spreads as some weaker competitors leave the industry. CMC has already proven that one of the strengths of its platform is the ability to adapt the technology to meet regulatory changes, which leaves the group well placed compared to many competitors. CMC is trading on an EV/EBITDA (annualised to December 2018) of c8x, which in our view inherently discounts a pessimistic outcome from these regulations, and fails to recognise the strength of the platform and improved market position. We therefore retain our Buy recommendation and target price of 210p.

BE11:48am

As the CFD industry matures and regulation is introduced to restrict the activities of the less scrupulous providers, we believe IG's market position should improve. We see this enhancing the quality of the group's income and believe its best in class practice will ensure that it is less negatively impacted from regulatory change. We expect the number of providers to shrink, as many of IG's smaller competitors are already struggling to break even. IG have guided that they expect the ESMA measures to reduce revenues by less than 10% and we have already included this in our forecasts.

BE11:48am

Shore .....

11:48 am
BE11:49am

We do not expect to make material change to our forecasts for IG Group^ (IGG, Hold at 816p) or CMC Markets^ (CMCX, Hold at 159p) as we had already factored in the ESMA measures as proposed. Note that the stringent rules, particularly on leverage limits, have led these two operators to highlight to clients the ability to elect to be treated as professional investors (subject to meeting certain FCA tests) who are exempt from these measures. This will substantially mitigate the overall impact.

red it really depends on how far they go in wanting proof on professional background for those that dont have 500 grand as you suspect most will knock back a dozen trades a month.

BE11:50am

And Liberum.

BE11:50am

he final measures from ESMA on regulating the provision of CFDs to retail investors in the EU are largely in line with expectations. We expect implementation by July'18. While the exact impact on revenues from leverage restrictions is difficult to estimate accurately, our forecasts for Plus500 already reflect 2019 ARPU to be 24% below the 2016 level on account of the restrictions confirmed today. We expect downgrades to consensus PBT estimates for IG Group of c.10%+ following their announcement this morning that revenue in FY19 in expected to be lower versus FY18. Plus500's valuation remains compelling, at 6.9x CY18 EPS falling to 6.6x and a yield of 8.7% versus IG Group trading at 15.0x CY18 EPS rising to 16.0x and yielding 4.7%. Reiterate BUY on Plus500.

Implications for Plus500: While the exact impact on revenues from leverage restrictions is difficult to estimate accurately, and Plus500 have not communicated an estimated impact, our forecasts already reflect 2019 ARPU to be 24% below the 2016 level on account of the restrictions confirmed today. Therefore, we remain comfortable with our forecasts.

red losing binary will hurt bottom lines for those that offer it. a huge money spinner for the brokers. the digital one armed bandit.
BE11:52am

Implications for IG Group: IG state they are "disappointed" by the proposals and continue to flag an impact of c.10% to revenues if the leverage restrictions were applied to historic revenues, on the basis that at least 50% of clients are classified as "professional". The company states that it expects revenue in "FY19 will be lower than that expected in FY18, primarily reflecting the impact of the regulatory changes in the UK and EU" and also flags that cryptocurrency trading is "unlikely to be as strong in the next financial year." We note consensus per Bloomberg shows £546m FY19 revenues, which feels too optimistic versus £559m for FY18 based on the company's comments today. We suggest c.£500m revenues feels more realistic, which implies a c.10%+ PBT downgrade versus current consensus.

We remain cautious as we think company and sellside expectations are too high for H2, H&M may not be able to sustain its dividend and we are not convinced that management is doing enough to address the fundamental issues with the H&M brand.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Post the Q1 we have left our PBT forecasts broadly unchanged with a small improvement in gross margin versus prior expectations but also slightly higher opex. Prior to today we were 10-12% below PBT consensus for FY18-19, and while we expect the gap to close we still see downside risk to sellside estimates and particularly to company expectations of "a somewhat better result for full year 2018 compared with the previous year". This will require clearly positive LFL sales growth along with strong (greater than 100bps) gross margin improvement, which we think will be challenging given an intensely competitive apparel sector.

BE11:59am

The main negative feature for Q1 was an ongoing high inventory position for H&M, at 17.4% of sales versus 16.9% at the end of Q4. H&M continues to be aggressive in clearing stock, particularly online, and we think there is a risk that constant promotions are losing their power to drive sales and also question whether the main H&M brand will be tarnished going forward.

BE11:59am

It's not all bad news for H&M. H&M still expects online sales and new brand sales to grow at 25% this year, which we think is achievable, albeit we see downside risk to store-based sales. And although the US and several major European markets remain challenging, H&M is now showing some progress in China with a recent successful launch on Tmall, although this is likely to prove margin dilutive owing to high fees. In addition H&M is very leveraged to a stronger euro trend, which will help its top line materially this year and next, and also provide it with buying gains. However, by the sounds of it H&M plans to retain some of these in H2, whereas we think a more radical investment in H&M product and service standards is required, along with a more radical rationalization of its store estate in response to channel shift online.
